body.p:
His Exl B. Magoffin Esqr
Governor of Kentucky

Your petitioner George W Murray states that some time about the 20th of December last he was fined $15 before the police court of the town of Crab Orchard for an alledged breach of the peace committed in the following maner. One Granville Roberts and James Johnson got in to a fight. Roberts was intoxicted and Johnson was beating him with a stick Roberts drew a bowie knife but Johnson knocked it out of his hands with a stick and was proceeding to further beat him and your petitioner being present and not wishing to see the man unnecessarily beat up he picked up the knife and ordered Johnson not to strike Roberts any more. I did not attempted to use the knife but threatened to do so if they did not cease beating Roberts and for this they arraigned him and fined him $15. and five days imprisionment. and imprisioned him five days in the tow county Jail

Your petitioner thinks he did not commit any breach of the peace and thinks five days imprisionment sufficient punishment for all the offence he committed if any.
he is a single man, and poor and Just beginning in the world and is endeavering to get his living by honest labor, and thinks it hard that he should pay the fine for nothing he thinks that if he had been tried by any other court he would not have been fined as he is advised all such fines go to the town. he says he is an orderly quiet man. And prays your Excellency to remit the fine
Sworn to before me the day of August 1861
E. T. Fish, C. P. C. C
We the undersigned residents in and near Crab Orchard state we are acquainted with young Mr. Murray and believe the fine ought to be remitted

D. N. Williams
James M. Cramp
